children.subject:
I don't know where you hear people say this but there is no such "suggested" GPA for internships/jobs. *Very few* employers even have a minimum GPA, most don't care, especially after a few years out of school it's not even talked about. I don't list mine on my resume and if the employer really wants to know they can ask.

It seems like we're going down the ladder with these posts - is 3.3 good enough? is 3.1 good enough? Is 2.9 good enough? Yes to all of them. There are people I know with a 2.3 who got top internships/jobs. What matters more is how well you prepare for your interviews, your skills, what you've built, etc. Focus on that more than a number that you probably won't even remember 10 years down the line. Just my 2 cents :)
Assuming that you have a 3.5, yes it's enough. Gotten interviews for Amazon/FB/Googs and got a FT job from one with a 3.54.

Yep!

also, as someone said above, I have heard from many friends with below 3.0s who got interviews at those competitive companies Joyce listed, among others, and got offers from many of them for internships and full time.

And I’m sure there’s tons more who did the same.

Build projects and your skills. You can do that with online tutorials. Go hit up alumni. Have a well formatted resume that presents your skills well. GPA should be insignificant to your worries about being rejected. There are way better ways to market yourself.

history.content: 2.0 is enough for full time offers. Graduating with CS degree and projects is enough because software engineering is so in demand. Raise your chances by having a past internship.

In light of @9230. I often hear people say 3.5 is the "suggested" gpa for securing a job position, but I want to know is this really good enough (in a sense that I don't need to concern about it too much and I can put more effort on projects / interview, etc) ?
history.subject: Is a 3.5 GPA good enough for internship / full-time job?
